@aravindmani-1 and @prgeor can you please share the refactored sfp change which is related to this change?

> @aravindmani-1 and @prgeor can you please share the refactored sfp change which is related to this change?

https://github.com/Azure/sonic-platform-common/blob/77da9c8440dda385db745c070453ff343acc1eac/sonic_platform_base/sonic_xcvr/api/public/cmis.py#L160

@aravindmani-1 and @prgeor - There are corresponding changes required in sonic-mgmt platform tests to accommodate this change. Specifically:
- https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/common/platform/transceiver_utils.py#L81
- https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/platform_tests/api/test_sfp.py#L78

Could you please make the appropriate change in sonic-mgmt as well.

> @aravindmani-1 and @prgeor - There are corresponding changes required in sonic-mgmt platform tests to accommodate this change. Specifically:
>

why I changed 7 jobs to 1 job? Because 7 parallel jobs didn't save time. They waste a lot of time downloading the same container and same artifacts.

is this a bug fix?

Yes. I believe it's gone unnoticed because most platforms end up returning these fields as string (rather than int) and the tests don't verify the types of these fields.

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging e7601d88cd2373bb189df64fb00ce7b9cad97d64 into d0be6342d8001842107aacb836dd7c1661e7eee6 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-platform-daemons/rev/pr-3f0a9fc20b5a4cac5aecb29259f4b4165af4e974)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Syntax error
Also please update PR description, as it references `chassisshow`, which is not part of this PR.
Just curious why a separate script is necessary for this. Why can we not simply add this logic to chassisd when it starts up?

We decided on a separate script because chassisd is primarily for handling modular chassis management (and thus is only run on modular chassis platforms), a separate task from uploading basic information such as serial, model, and hardware revision that is applicable to all platforms and also one-shot.

Since this script is a one-shot script, and not a daemon per se, I have reservations about adding it in this repo. We could simply add it in the buildimage repo as part of https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/7596. However, it would not be built into a package, so we would not be able to run unit tests against it. I'm on the fence, but I guess I can live with having it as part of the chassisd package.

I would argue that while the name `sonic-platform-daemons` does indicate a one-shot task wouldn't belong, architecturally it does belong here as it performs the same fundamental task as the chassisd daemon (uploading chassis information to the redis db). As such anyone looking for this code would likely expect to find it here and I think that is valuable. 

If there exists now or in the future a collection of one-shot tasks for the purpose of provisioning redis then I would argue this should be refactored at that point.

> architecturally it does belong here as it performs the same fundamental task as the chassisd daemon (uploading chassis information to the redis db).

I agree with this, which is why I am on the fence.

> If there exists now or in the future a collection of one-shot tasks for the purpose of provisioning redis then I would argue this should be refactored at that point.

Agreed. We can proceed with this PR.
@jleveque , @daall can you please review this PR?.

This PR can safely be merged without the Mellanox implementation (as it has to be tolerant of other vendor non-implemented status) it just won't do anything.

@robocoder99: Can you please also add a regression test for `get_revision()` in https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/platform_tests/api/test_psu.py to ensure vendors are aware they need to implement the new method for their platforms?
Yes, that is in progress (done but in Mellanox internal review)

@jleveque I'll try testing your change today

I tried your change and it's behaving similarly to the old one.
I couldn't verify by looking at a dut but I enabled some debug traces in our plugin to verify the calls.

Something that I realized is that changing a port from `up` to `down` or vice versa generates 10+ calls to `port_link_status_change`.
From up to down I saw 9 up events and 3 down events.
From down to up I saw 11 down events and 1 up event.

> I tried your change and it's behaving similarly to the old one.
> I couldn't verify by looking at a dut but I enabled some debug traces in our plugin to verify the calls.
